Message.Title: Should the FBI INVESTIGATE GOOGLE THEMSELVES
Message.Msg: It is estimated that the entire android operating system contains malware in different disguises. Some of these cannot be screened successfully by Google themselves in the Google Play store. So what do we have? If you own a Android OS phone you are being spied on, used as a gateway to your employer or used to generate google ad clicks. So let's look at the last one 'being used to generate ad click revenue on google ads. That means there are criminals using your browser to go to web sites and click a google paid ad. The so called criminal generate money by placing google ad sense ads themselves. This allows other peoples ads to be displayed on their own website. They get a portion of the money every time someone click the paid ad and google get's the rest. The looser is the business that pays advertising and is being clicked on by malware bots with not interest in buying anything that the advertiser hoped to sell. Google has said they are Russian organized crime placing malware in apps and you download an app or it is pre installed and you phone or computer is accessing pages and clicking on ads without you knowing it. Google has indicated that 20% are not able to be detected by Google screening prior to shipping the device or letting it be downloaded in the google play store. Really? Possibilities: 1.) It is like google says, they simply cannot detect it even though Microsoft can and does not have the same problem. 2.) Google is actually not attempting to make Android 100% safe as they are earning Billions of dollars in these phony bogus ad clicks. They are making un imaginable amounts of money on this scam. 3.) Ex or current google engineers who know the system are involved. Everyone Else but Google has been able to manage this problem Apple & Microsoft do not have the malware in the stores, phones or machines. So we all know that the Android OS is given away for free & Linux based. Does the FBI need to see if maybe it is not so free after all. I think so.

Message.Title: Should Microsoft Kill Windows 8 Immediately?
Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting: "Microsoft (NASDAQ: MSFT ) Windows 8 is totally killing the PC market. As if PC shipments weren't already stagnating, Windows 8 just knocked unit volumes down for the count. "The 14% decline in the first quarter that IDC estimated is the worst quarterly contraction in nearly 20 years. There were initial indications that Windows 8 wasn't taking off, such as when IDC pegged fourth-quarter PC units at negative 6.4%. The new operating system was released about a month into that quarter, so it was fair to say then that Windows 8 maybe just needed some time. It was simply too early to call it for sure. "Well, we can now call it for sure: Windows 8 has bombed. Don't just take my word for it. IDC's Bob O'Donnell makes it quite clear: " At this point, unfortunately, it seems clear that the Windows 8 launch not only failed to provide a positive boost to the PC market, but appears to have slowed the market. While some consumers appreciate the new form factors and touch capabilities of Windows 8, the radical changes to the UI, removal of the familiar Start button, and the costs associated with touch have made PCs a less attractive alternative to dedicated tablets and other competitive devices. Microsoft will have to make some very tough decisions moving forward if it wants to help reinvigorate the PC market. "Windows 8 was a huge risk. It was a risk that Microsoft needed to take in the face of lackluster global PC shipments, but after five months on the market, the data show that consumers just aren't buying into Microsoft's vision, literally and figuratively. Users want the Start Menu back; some certified technicians even offer services to downgrade brand-new PCs back to Windows 7 (that'll be $125, please), allowing users to go back to the familiar interface and embrace of that OS." __________________________________________ I'm not making it up, folks. But softie shills will never get it.

Topic.Title: Should the Motley Fool be Killed Immediatly?

Message.Title: wealth
Message.Msg: When wealth is spread out among many people they have increased discretionary spending power. When they buy things it helps the economy. Conversely, when wealth is concentrated in great amounts held by a relatively few number of people there is a lack of wealth distribution; and most people have little discretionary spending power. They don't buy as much; so the economy slows down. That is what had been happening for the last 35 years. It is better for the economy for most people to be doing fairly well than it is for a few to be doing extremely well and most people just getting by. Therefore, in order to improve our economy we should be looking for ways to reduce wealth inequality. Raising the minimum wage is one way to ensure that the lower paid workers have more buying power. Another way would be to limit the income of the executives of large corporations to a multiple of their average workers income. Breaking up the largest corporations and banks so that there is more competition in markets would also help. Increased unionization also reduces wealth inequality. It would be very beneficial to take away the special treatment the biggest banks get from the Federal Reserve and allow market forces to work naturally. "The primary mechanism for uploading wealth is debt-based creation of new money under the system of fractional reserve lending under the central control of the private bank-owned Federal Reserve, which supplies money, at interest, to the U.S. Government. Commercial banks create electronic entry money when they make loans, typically up to ten times the amount in their reserves. This contributes to cyclical asset hyperinflation bubbles and busts, in which the Big Five money-center banks are key players and from which the super-wealthy emerge relatively wealthier. This has resulted in a virtually permanent super-elite." "In 2007 the richest 1% of the American population owned 34.6% of the country's total wealth, and the next 19% owned 50.5%. Thus, the

Message.Title: Surface RT
Message.Msg: I dumped my iPad for a Surface RT a few days ago and couldn't be happier. With a real keyboard (I bought the one with typewritter-type keys for $30 extra) MS Office, a USB port and a SD card slof I can actaully do work with the Surface. Windows 8 works well once you learn the various ways to swipe across the screen. The fact that you can easly access the same informtion the day way on a phone, tablet and computer is a smart idea. I think MSFT is on the right track, even if a lot of people don't know it yer.
